reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s key move in Section 2.4: modeling future value as multiplicative across (roughly) independent dimensions, which supports the claim that mostly-great futures are rare (“fragile eutopia”). This is an important pillar, but not the only pillar (the essay also argues via population ethics/scale, rights for digital beings, bounded vs unbounded value functions, aggregation of goods/bads, etc.), so centrality is substantial but not total. The critique’s main point is strong: the product/independence assumptions are doing most of the work in turning ‘many important considerations’ into ‘exponentially small target,’ and alternative plausible structures (threshold/plateau, redundancy, substitutability, correlation among dimensions) could make high-value futures much less rare. However, it does not show that the essay’s multiplicative picture is false or even unlikely; it mostly identifies under-argued assumptions and suggests what would be needed to justify them, so it weakens rather than refutes. The claims are largely correct: independence/non-substitutability/catastrophic shortfalls are indeed required for the exponential-rarity conclusion, and the threshold/plateau counter-model is a coherent alternative. Clarity is high and dead weight is minimal. It is mostly a single focused issue, though it has a few sub-conditions (correlation, substitutability, catastrophe vs marginal), all in service of the same objection.
title: Threshold-based moral structures would make good futures common, not rare
